Title: Post Scriptum: A Digital Archive of Ordinary Writings (Early Modern Portugal and Spain)

This project proposes to create a comprehensive digital archive of personal letters written by ordinary individuals in 17th to early 19th century Portugal and Spain. Focusing on the writings of servants, children, wives, lovers, thieves, soldiers, artisans, priests, and political fighters, this archive will provide a unique window into the daily lives and experiences of non-elite individuals during this period. The letters, often produced in the context of interactions with institutions such as the Inquisition and civil courts, will be systematically collected, edited, and subjected to historical-linguistic study. Sociological interviews will also be conducted to provide additional context. The project's output will include a large collection assembly, online digital edition, philological treatment, and cultural and linguistic study. Employing rigorous editing standards based on Textual Criticism, this archive will facilitate a well-contextualized study of inter-personal modes of relation and traditional communities. The letters' content, characterized by oral rhetoric, emotional expression, commonsense statements, and narration of trivial incidents, will offer a fresh perspective on the social and cultural history of early modern Iberia.
